Probably something to do with how much data those UTXOs require during a transaction. I don‚Äôt know enough yet but fees are definitely different with UTXOs that contain digits in the very small decimals.
I‚Äôve done a little UTXO consolidation recently so that‚Äôs where I noticed it. But idk what the best strategy is
How? I've yet to explore this
I connected my Trezor to Sparrow Wallet. Sparrow Wallet let‚Äôs you see all your UTXOs, so you can select all the ones you want to consolidate, and send them to yourself with a new address.

bump
Can you explain who owns what in the pic you posted here?
Is the only purpose of CoinJoins to obscure who owns which UTXO? Or are there other technical things that it‚Äôs used for and the enhanced privacy aspect is a nice bonus?
Is that more effective than sending sats to lightning/liquid and then back to on chain?
Since lighting provides some level of privacy...Eugene is asking if coinjoining is better/worse than that method
I recently learned that sending KYC sats to Liquid and then from Liquid back to on chain will break the link between your initial and final UTXOs because of the privacy on the Liquid chain

So on the left there are two UTXOs as inputs (presumably from 2 different individuals) and then on the right are the 4 outputs (also presumably 2 individuals). At the end of it, it‚Äôs not possible to know for sure which two outputs are owned by which person. Is that correct?
Why would someone do a fake coinjoin? Do you mean that it's a "bad attempt at a coinjoin"?
So it's a lesser version of a coinjoin. Not as good
